rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 With the engineer lab.}
{\rtf1 What we're basically trying to do is\par figure out how can I enable a whole bunch}
{\rtf1 of well-built rules tagged\par with MITRE techniques already}
{\rtf1 provided by the Sigma project.\par Let's support them with our tools,}
{\rtf1 our SIEMs, our detection products.}
{\rtf1 And so what we're going to do is we're\par going to see how a Sigma rule looks}
{\rtf1 natively and how we can convert it\par into our different tool formats,}
{\rtf1 new, more vendor lock in.}
{\rtf1 Now we can use a tool called\par sigmac and convert it to use}
{\rtf1 PowerShell, grep, elasticsearch\par elastalert, Splunk, you name it.}
{\rtf1 It's often built into the tool\par by default. So we'll use that.}
{\rtf1 And we'll also use this because\par if I convert tools using Sigma}
{\rtf1 signatures,}
{\rtf1 I can also build a heat map to\par see what automated alert tech}
{\rtf1 capabilities we have using\par the MITRE attack framework.}
{\rtf1 So if I take one of the\par earlier labs, the detect lab,}
{\rtf1 and I mapped that against what we\par have now with our alert output,}
{\rtf1 I now can see what my visibility\par is. Plus my detection capabilities.}
{\rtf1 And now I have a full, complete picture\par of what I have. So in the engineer lab,}
{\rtf1 we're going to implement the automatic\par output of rules into our format.}
{\rtf1 So here we go. We're going to\par go to the Sigma engineer lab,}
{\rtf1 inland from here,}
{\rtf1 we're going to dive into converting\par rules like this signal rule}
{\rtf1 into the format that we need\par for our SIEMs. I noticing here,}
{\rtf1 I've got a title. I've got a\par unique identifier. I've got status.}
{\rtf1 Maybe you might not want to\par convert experimental rules.}
{\rtf1 That's something we can handle. I've got\par referenced links to articles about it.}
{\rtf1 MITRE tagging what data source the\par rule would apply to and the actual}
{\rtf1 detection logic.}
{\rtf1 So what we want to do is\par use this information and\par convert it into things like}
{\rtf1 this. This is an elastalert rule format.}
{\rtf1 Elastalert is an alert engine.}
{\rtf1 A that's a freebie designed by\par Yelp for elasticsearch data.}
{\rtf1 Well,}
{\rtf1 I would need the alert above converted\par into this format in order for me to}
{\rtf1 find the attack.}
{\rtf1 So the cool thing is this is\par something that's easily handled.}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to do is we're going\par to play with converting the same rule}
{\rtf1 to three different formats\par and Elasticsearch search\par format and the elastalert}
{\rtf1 format, and then a Splunk\par format. So here we go.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to open a terminal. I'm\par just going to run these commands.}
{\rtf1 So this first one is\par basically saying run the Sigma}
{\rtf1 conversion tools,}
{\rtf1 Sigmac convert the rule to the\par engine type of Elasticsearch rule}
{\rtf1 and use the default field\par specified by Winlogbeat}
{\rtf1 the alert rule that we're converting\par is this rule and notice it's this}
{\rtf1 JSON output. If you want to read it a\par little bit easier, you can do pipe JQ,}
{\rtf1 and that'll pretty printed to screen.\par So notice with the elasticsearch out,}
{\rtf1 but it kept the references.}
{\rtf1 It kept the MITRE attack techniques\par and it has the actual query}
{\rtf1 elasticsearch would need. Well,}
{\rtf1 let's see what happens when I convert\par it to elastalert. So different tool.}
{\rtf1 Again,}
{\rtf1 notice I'm still using\par the Winlogbeat fields}
{\rtf1 cause it's still technically an\par Elasticsearch database, same rule,}
{\rtf1 but at the engines now elastalert\par this time and outputs is a YAML file}
{\rtf1 and it has the description in the\par query. There is no references.}
{\rtf1 There's no MITRE techniques because well,}
{\rtf1 the elastalert doesn't need it to work.}
{\rtf1 And the same thing is true when\par we test Splunk. So here we go.}
{\rtf1 A Splunk, copy that, right?}
{\rtf1 Let me make sure I got\par that right. There we go.}
{\rtf1 Engine of Splunk, it's using the\par default Splunk windows fields.}
{\rtf1 As if you use like a, say a universal\par forwarder and same exact rule.}
{\rtf1 Notice it basically\par builds out a query for us,}
{\rtf1 but I don't have references. I\par don't have the MITRE techniques.}
{\rtf1 It's not a problem. I\par get a nice alert rule,}
{\rtf1 but I've got to do a little bit more\par leg work before I start automatically}
{\rtf1 putting this rule in place.}
{\rtf1 So the rest of the lab\par is basically doing that.}
{\rtf1 One thing we're doing right off the\par bat is I want that additional data}
{\rtf1 personally, in my alert rules.}
{\rtf1 So for example, when I converted to\par elastalert, I lost those MITRE attacks.}
{\rtf1 We're going to put them back.}
{\rtf1 So if I go in here and I push\par control G on the keyboard and I go to}
{\rtf1 line 10 29,}
{\rtf1 this is the section where it\par controls how to output an elastalert}
{\rtf1 rule. And what we're going to do is\par instead of just having name, description,}
{\rtf1 index priority, and real alert,}
{\rtf1 we're going to add in the MITRE\par information back into the law.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to go here, paste\par it, get rid of that new line.}
{\rtf1 And then I'm going to hit control S to\par save it. You also could do a file save.}
{\rtf1 And then from there we can\par test to see if this worked.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to reconvert\par that rule we have,}
{\rtf1 and it should have changed. Notice.}
{\rtf1 Now it brought over the MITRE information.}
{\rtf1 Now elastalert doesn't natively\par use that to detect things,}
{\rtf1 but I now have it as\par context for my analysts.}
{\rtf1 It's like additional tags or fields,}
{\rtf1 which can be helpful during\par an investigation. So we\par just put that in place.}
{\rtf1 Now, the trick to me here is,}
{\rtf1 is I want to make this a more\par automated implementation.}
{\rtf1 So what I'm going to do,}
{\rtf1 and what I would encourage you to\par do is run this bash grip, start it.}
{\rtf1 It's going to take a while.}
{\rtf1 Cause it's going to convert\par all the prebuilt Sigma rules.}
{\rtf1 And then as it's running,}
{\rtf1 the rest of this lab kind of walks you\par through what the script's doing and how}
{\rtf1 you could modify it for your environment.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to go ahead\par and start this, let it run.}
{\rtf1 And then we'll pick back up and I'll walk\par through what this is doing while it's}
{\rtf1 converting. So you can see here, it's\par starting to convert all the rules,}
{\rtf1 let that run in the\par background, go back here.}
{\rtf1 And then we'll start to analyze\par what the script's doing. Note,}
{\rtf1 everything's going to be slow while it's\par converting all the rules that's normal.}
{\rtf1 So just let it go ahead and do its thing\par and continue with the lab while it's,}
{\rtf1 while it's running in the background.}
{\rtf1 So, what we're going to do is we're going\par to open the script while it's running.}
{\rtf1 We'll open a new terminal at the other\par one, continue running in the background.}
{\rtf1 You also could have just browse to this}
{\rtf1 and notice here,}
{\rtf1 the top of the script is\par basically just variables.}
{\rtf1 It's just things that you\par might change like, um,}
{\rtf1 and this one I'm converting the rules\par to elastalert. Maybe you use Splunk,}
{\rtf1 you would change that. Splunk, the\par template set to Winlogbeat. Again,}
{\rtf1 if you use Splunk, you'd need to match\par the default template you want to use,}
{\rtf1 or your custom one. And\par since I'm using elastalert,}
{\rtf1 if I was doing automatic rule testing,}
{\rtf1 I would also fill out this information.}
{\rtf1 It's basically letting me do key based\par authentication to elastic search.}
{\rtf1 And it lets me automatically\par submit queries against it using}
{\rtf1 the config and this YAML file from here,}
{\rtf1 where do I want Sigma rules to be placed?}
{\rtf1 And where are the rules specifically out\par that we're converting and then where do}
{\rtf1 I want to output them to? And if\par I'm doing MITRE heat map generation,}
{\rtf1 where's the conversion tool.}
{\rtf1 And if I'm converting the\par rules with automated testing,}
{\rtf1 where do I want to place them?}
{\rtf1 If they go into production versus\par require manually reviewed or are}
{\rtf1 slow and again, need reviewed.}
{\rtf1 You control what the script does here.}
{\rtf1 Do you want to run prereq checks?\par Do you want to convert rules?}
{\rtf1 Do you want to clean up old rules?}
{\rtf1 Do you want to automatically test\par your rules after they're converted?}
{\rtf1 And do you want to build\par a heat map for this lab?}
{\rtf1 All we're simply doing is converting\par the rules and cleaning up old rules}
{\rtf1 before that conversion. So basically\par this is how we're controlling,}
{\rtf1 what it does. We don't have\par pre-recs enabled, but if we did,}
{\rtf1 you'll notice it basically installs\par get so that I could get clone the Sigma}
{\rtf1 GitHub repository. If you\par didn't have it, it installs JQ.}
{\rtf1 So it can parse and pull off fields as\par part of this operation, as well as YQ,}
{\rtf1 which is for YAML files.}
{\rtf1 Then it'll check to see if the Sigma\par folder exists. And if it doesn't it does,}
{\rtf1 they get clone. That's\par all the prerequisites do.}
{\rtf1 The core of this is the conversion,\par which is actually pretty simple.}
{\rtf1 Go to the rules folder, look,\par and grab every single file name.}
{\rtf1 You can store it into this\par variable. This array called files,}
{\rtf1 then loop through them.\par One file at a time.}
{\rtf1 And here I'm building a custom file name.}
{\rtf1 I'll grab the original signal\par file name, it's unique ID,}
{\rtf1 and then I'll output it with\par the file name, underscore ID,}
{\rtf1 and then ending with dot YAML.}
{\rtf1 So here we'll see that Sigmac tool would\par get ran with whatever alert engine you}
{\rtf1 specified up top and the template.}
{\rtf1 And it would output with\par that custom file name.}
{\rtf1 And it just loops through these over\par and over. And then when it's done,}
{\rtf1 it'll find any files that are\par empty and it'll delete them.}
{\rtf1 Cause those would be rules that for\par whatever reason, didn't convert correctly.}
{\rtf1 So pretty rare. But if it does\par happen, this will clean them up.}
{\rtf1 We do not have for this\par lab rule testing enabled}
{\rtf1 this script. If it does rule\par testing, it's kind of cool.}
{\rtf1 It will spin off a Docker\par container and test using historical}
{\rtf1 production data. The rule that\par you just converted, all of them.}
{\rtf1 So one by one, it'll fire up in this case,}
{\rtf1 a Docker container using\par elastalert config file,}
{\rtf1 and it will record how long\par did it take to check the data?}
{\rtf1 Did it find any matches or\par hits? And if it did well,}
{\rtf1 what does that mean?}
{\rtf1 So it'll go through this and it'll start\par to place the data in separate folders.}
{\rtf1 So for example, if an alert\par rule that was converted,}
{\rtf1 found something, I move it\par to a manual review folder,}
{\rtf1 cause either it found something and I'm\par compromised and I need to look into it}
{\rtf1 or it's a false positive,}
{\rtf1 and I need to tune the rule or maybe\par I want to delete the rule either way}
{\rtf1 someone needs to look at it.\par If it doesn't find anything,}
{\rtf1 but it's slow,}
{\rtf1 I move it to the slow folder because it,}
{\rtf1 the performance hit might not be\par worth the rule that it's checking.}
{\rtf1 So I might just, Nope,}
{\rtf1 not going to use that rule or maybe\par the rule just needs slightly tweaked.}
{\rtf1 So it's faster. Maybe the way it's,\par it's querying a field is wrong.}
{\rtf1 But if the rule is fast testing\par against production data,}
{\rtf1 and it doesn't find anything, I just\par move it into production. Why? Well,}
{\rtf1 hopefully the attack that it's trying\par to find has never occurred in my}
{\rtf1 environment, which is why\par I didn't find anything,}
{\rtf1 but the fact that it\par was fact or fast, well,}
{\rtf1 that now means that later, if\par it does well, I'll find it.}
{\rtf1 And the rule was fast. So the\par impact overall was insignificant.}
{\rtf1 So I move it directly into production.}
{\rtf1 And the last thing here is if you\par haven't built a MITRE attack, heat map,}
{\rtf1 a little do that for you as\par part of this. So the script,}
{\rtf1 even though it's 160 lines,}
{\rtf1 it's not actually doing too much and\par you could easily modify this to your}
{\rtf1 environment at this point, I\par think the output has done. Yep.}
{\rtf1 It is. So now what we're going to\par do is at the bottom of the lab,}
{\rtf1 what we've done so far is kind of talk\par through the lab is it has us build}
{\rtf1 a heat map using this command right here.\par So I'm going to go ahead and run this.}
{\rtf1 And what it's going to do is it generates\par a MITRE attack, navigator heat map.}
{\rtf1 I'm gonna go to MITRE attack navigator.}
{\rtf1 I'm gonna load this and we'll see what\par coverage we would have had with the}
{\rtf1 default windows for Sigma. Yeah.}
{\rtf1 These came directly from the Sigma\par project. I didn't create any of them.}
{\rtf1 It's just, what's in the\par GitHub project by default.}
{\rtf1 So you only to go to the root of\par the drive, the temp open heat map,}
{\rtf1 you'll get this warning about it being\par an older version of the heat map,}
{\rtf1 which is fine. Doesn't\par really affect too much.}
{\rtf1 And now notice the colors by\par default are this shades of}
{\rtf1 red. You could change the\par color setup if you want. Uh,}
{\rtf1 I will often do something\par like you could do}
{\rtf1 a yellow}
{\rtf1 and then change the value to something\par like five and notice that makes it quite}
{\rtf1 a bit easier to see. So\par things that are deep red,}
{\rtf1 you have multiple rules when\par you hovered, you can see it,}
{\rtf1 things that are yellow, you at\par least have some coverage. Uh, and}
{\rtf1 actually I'm going to\par change white to yellow.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to change this middle\par one to orange. Here we go.}
{\rtf1 And things that are white.\par Now you have no coverage.}
{\rtf1 So you do have to be a little\par careful because the technique,}
{\rtf1 the old 2.2 you'll notice I have\par something for bypass user control,}
{\rtf1 but it shows the parent\par as not having anything.}
{\rtf1 I can tell there's something\par there, cause it said one to four,}
{\rtf1 but it can be somewhat misleading because\par in the newer version of navigator,}
{\rtf1 there's now sub techniques.\par So you'll see it like that.}
{\rtf1 But this,}
{\rtf1 this is our default rule coverage\par with the generic rules that come with}
{\rtf1 Sigma, they're free.}
{\rtf1 You just convert them to your tool\par and magically you get them as you}
{\rtf1 add your own rules. If you also\par write them in Sigma format,}
{\rtf1 it will be included in this heat map\par because you'll have those MITRE techniques}
{\rtf1 in the Sigma generic rule format.}
{\rtf1 And so now you can just build this out\par more and more and more and magically}
{\rtf1 that you've engineered this\par it's implemented and you can}
{\rtf1 automatically have this report\par to tag off to leadership.}
{\rtf1 And so the lab kind of ends here and I\par would encourage you try to go back home}
{\rtf1 and implement the automation behind\par this because you can pull down new rules}
{\rtf1 plus bring in your custom rules and\par they double feed into the system.}
